Speaker.P: I am having enquiry made into this matter, but according to present information the address mentioned is not among the posts occupied by the Civic Guard from July to October.

Speaker.hpid: LIAM O BRIAIN LIAM O BRIAIN
Speaker.P: To ask the Minister for Defence whether Philip O'Neill, Organiser, Irish Transport and General Workers' Union, Birr, was arrested some months ago, and is still in custody; whether he signed the form on December 31st applying for his release, and giving the required undertaking not to use arms against the Government; why he has not been released, and whether it is now proposed to release him, or, in the alternative, bring him to trial.

Speaker.hpid: MINISTER for DEFENCE (General Mulcahy) Richard (General) Mulcahy
Speaker.P: Mr. O'Neill was arrested on the 12th November last and is still in custody. He signed the usual form of undertaking on the 30th December. His release was, however, not considered advisable in view of the fact that during a search of his house, in consequence of firing on our troops in the neighbourhood, pistol ammunition and a large quantity of field dressings were found in his possession. It is proposed to formulate a charge against him and to put him on trial.

MainHeading.Title: [WRITTEN ANSWERS.] - CLAIM FOR COMMANDEERED MOTOR CAR.

Speaker.hpid: TOMAS O CONAILL TOMAS O CONAILL
Speaker.P: To ask the Minister for Defence if he is aware that a new Ford car was commandeered in Urlingford, from Mr. Wm. P. Walker, on July 14th, 1922, by Commandant M`Carthy of the Second Southern Division, that this car was afterwards captured by the Irregulars, that, despite several applications, Mr. Walker has yet received no compensation for the loss of his car, and will the Minister give instructions that this long overdue claim is immediately dealt with.

The car was commandeered by our troops and captured by Irregulars as stated. It has only recently become possible to deal with claims for compensation in respect of commandeered motor cars. Mr. Walker's claim will receive early attention.

Speaker.hpid: TOMAS O CONAILL TOMAS O CONAILL
Speaker.P: To ask the Minister for Defence if he is aware that a Ford car was taken on September 6th, 1922, by the National Forces from Mr. William L. Smyth, M.R.C.V.S., Ballyhaunis, Co. Mayo; that a claim for compensation was lodged last November with the Army Finance Department, and as Mr. Smyth is very seriously hampered in his work as a Veterinary Surgeon by the loss of his car, will the Minister see that his claim receives immediate attention.

I am informed that the car was not taken but was asked for by our troops and given by Mr. Smyth on the 6th September. A claim for compensation has been received and is being investigated. The investigations will be expedited.

Speaker.hpid: TOMAS O CONAILL TOMAS O CONAILL
Speaker.P: To ask the Minister for Defence if he is aware that out of a sum of £583 11s. due to Mrs. Murtagh, of the Moy Hotel, Ballina, for the billeting of troops, only £124 16s. has yet been paid, that several applications for payment have been made without result; that in consequence Mrs. Murtagh finds herself considerably hampered in the conduct of her business, and will he give instructions for the immediate payment of this long overdue account.
The account received from Mrs. Murtagh in the first instance amounted to £398 11s. 6d. Portion of it was for damage to furniture, etc., in, and for articles missing from, the Hotel.

The amount appears to be excessive, but will be assessed as expeditiously as possible. The balance, £192 4s. 6d. in respect of billeting was reduced to £124 16s. 0d. and a cheque in settlement issued.

An account was received from Mrs. Murtagh's solicitors amounting to £583 0s. 11d., which included the £398 11s. 6d. which I have just mentioned. They were written to on the 22nd January and asked to furnish details of the balance of the account. These details have not yet been received.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. THOMAS O'CONNELL Mr. THOMAS O'CONNELL
Speaker.P: I beg to give notice that on the motion for the adjournment of the Dáil I will raise the question of the action of the military in seizing cattle on certain lands in Galway and elsewhere and selling them.
